channel.name: How to commit the hash of a file onchain in a provable way?

messages.content: I need one function that hashes a file and stores that hash on chain, and another function that verifies the hash stored on chain matches the local file. Both functions would take in the file as input in some encoding. I was trying stringsToFields and bytesToFields until I realized that neither can be proven inside the circuit.
I feel like i'm missing something simple here and going about it in a roundabout way lol, any advice or ideas are welcome.

Here's how i'm currently doing it: 
1. Convert the file (.txt in this case) into a utf-8 string. 
2. Apply stringToFields() to get a Field []. 
3. Now, in order to prove that I computed the Poseidon hashes correctly, I created a struct of 8 Field elements and a function that converts a Field [] into an array of these 8 Field structs.
4. Each 8 Field struct goes into a zkProgram recursive function that computes the Poseidon hashes of each set, using publicInput and publicOutput to basically aggregate all the Fields
5. the last set of 8 (truncating extra fields for now to reduce my headaches xD) turns into a final recursive proof, which can be submitted on chain as the commitment of the unit test.

The idea here is that later down the line, when the raw unit test is revealed, anyone can run this again to verify that the unit test hash submitted on chain is INDEED the hash that is computed from the unit test that was revealed. But again, this just seems like unneccesary computation but I have no idea how else this could be done, since arrays must have a fixed size and you can't prove something like stringToFields or bytesToFields inside a circuit.

I'm solving a similar problem in my project. I calculate SHA3-512 for all files and put the hash on-chain. It allows you to quickly check the integrity of the whole file off-chain by comparing on-chain and off-chain hashes.

To verify the file on-chain, I convert the file to Merkle Tree by using a tree.fill(), which is, btw very sloooooow. Then I put Merkle Tree root on-chain. It allows to prove any part of the file, including situations when only part of the file is disclosed to the verifier.

You can check the node code at
https://github.com/dfstio/minanft-lib/blob/master/src/storage/file.ts#L180
and web code at
https://github.com/dfstio/minanftio/blob/minanft/src/blockchain/file.js#L21

@devtonite You can achieve that with the following approach:

1. Hash the file off-Mina/O1JS (e.g. how @DFST does it in in getFileData()
2. Compute the Poseidon hash of the hash from step 1, in a verifiable manner (using O1JS ZKProgram or method on a SmartContract).
3. Store the hash from 2 on-chain

Please note, step 2 is crutial, otherwise you're not proving that you have that file locally, and anyone will be easily to make the claim that they have the file, by simply re-using the Hash value. By verifiably hashing the hash from point 1, your computation proves that it has access to some hash (which in our logic is derived from some file), whose "verifiable Poseidon hash" computes to a certain value.
there isn't any more efficient way that is practical right now with O1JS
you could employ advanced cryptography to do it but it's probably not worth your time
however you should try to do as much hashing in a single proof as possible since the overhead is mostly in the proof generation/verification
the proper way would be to implement a folding scheme and implement a verifier for that and do the hashing with the folding scheme (like Nova)
this is probably necessary if you want to hash huge files

If someone however implements a way to verify a WASM program or anything similar to O1JS, you could use some pre-existing stuff for that, compile verifier to WASM, and prove execution of that, which would be needlessly inefficient, but asymptotically much much better than what you'd have to do naively
@Las if you compute a commitment with any digest with pre-image resistance, second image resistance, and collision existence, you're effectively compressing the file into a fixed-lenght
From there just hash that fixed-length in O1JS
ah right I'm dumb, you can just hash it outside the circuit
@Las not dumb at all! These are little details that you'll get used to 😄

A general mindset that you will find useful with Zero-Knowledge applications is that everything must be fixed. All zero-knowledge circuits operate on a known set of data, with known dimensions (size in bytes). As such, when you're thinking of commiting somehting, think first about how you can "cryptographically compress it into fixed-lenght".

For example, you can't have a circuit that directly accepts an array of numbers. But you can have a circuit that accepts a number, and a previous commitment (e.g. recursive proof). Then, your circuit would extend the existing commitment with the new number, while outputting a fixed/known amount of data (size in bytes). As a general rule, you turn an arbitrary amount of data into fixed size through the use of hashing.

Ok that's seems to make sense. I was basically doing the same thing but by computing the Poseidon hash off chain, and then commiting it on chain as the "testCommitHash." But then I later realized that my smart contract wasn't checking anything because one could just copy the onchain hash and use it as their input (LMAO). Which is what eventually led me to the hacky solution I've come up with above.

THERE IT IS! I knew I was missing a simple idea. As I just mentioned, I was basically doing what you described in step 1, but was indeed missing step 2. Just Poseidon hash the single hash again to put that on chain. I'll try that right now.
Just add time to hash inputs and check every time that time is higher than previous)
Regarding the merkle tree approach for verifying it onchain, I'll have to see if my use case needs that.
I'm still learning how merkle trees work atm
do you mean add the "current time" as an additional input along side the file? so there's a time value connected to every hash?
I'm not sure I quite follow haha
Yes
ah gotcha
thanks!
Kind of salt
perfect yes that makes sense
that will also help me with being able to determine who submitted valid code solutions prior to the revealing on the unit test for testing
so other users can't spam submissions once they ALREADY know the unit test that's going to be computed
I'm indeed starting to better understand this concept as I build. Well said!
@devtonite I’m glad I helped, let me know if you have any further questions!

@devtonite on a related note, I wrote a blog post about recursive zkSNARKs in O1JS and Mina. You’ll find it very useful in understanding the deeper intricacies of the topics discussed on this thread.

You can find it here: https://illya.sh/blog/posts/zk-snarks-recursive-proof-private-intput-visibility/

No problem! Let me know if something is unclear or if you have furhter questions!
hey friend, I'm in the middle of reading through the calculator example, and i'd just like to say thank you for such a valuable resource 🙏

I've already learned so much. Really appreciate the code example especially, I didn't even know we could refactor our functions out of the ZKProgram and have separate circuits for the base and recursive case. It makes so much sense now in retrospect, but prior to reading your blog, I always found writing our o1js smart contracts kinda overwhelming and cumbersome to read.
Like, OF COURSE we can refactor LOL, It just did not occur to me until I saw your example. So thanks again for that, it's been helpful already.

Thank you for the kind words, and you are more than welcome! I’m ecstatic that you found value in it. These were questions and challenges that I also had at the start. As you continue learning, you will see that it will all start clicking together.

I have more blog posts like this one coming!

If you have any questions, please let me know!

Absolutely. It was well deserved. I finished reading through it all last night. I'm going to slowly try to start reading through zkLocus' codebase more. I like the organization but it was a little challenging to follow, so i'll be taking it one step at a time haha.
I was curious though, how did you implement the timing proof? I found the struct of start and end time but didn't understand where you get the time data from

Hey @devtonite apologies for the late reply, I just noticed it.

>  I'm going to slowly try to start reading through zkLocus' codebase more. I like the organization but it was a little challenging to follow, so i'll be taking it one step at a time haha.

Thank you so much!  There is little documentation for now, but I will be adding all of that. In the last commits, you can see more parts of the API being documents.

I suggest you start with the "api" module/folder: https://github.com/iluxonchik/zkLocus/tree/main/contracts/src/api

It contains the end-user API. This is the actual API that you would be using to create, verify and load Zero-Knowledge proofs.

The files in the "tests" folder is useful for understanding how to do something. For example, how do you use the integration oracle, how to generate, verify and load ZK proofs: https://github.com/iluxonchik/zkLocus/tree/main/contracts/src/tests

> I was curious though, how did you implement the timing proof? I found the struct of start and end time but didn't understand where you get the time data from

Regarding the time part, I have the structures ready, but I'm leaving the actual implementation for later. With regards to geolocation time, there are two important factors to consider:

1. Obtaining time in a verifiable/authenticated manner. The most simple way would be an Oracle, similar to  https://github.com/zkLocus/integration-oracle
2. Cryptographiclaly tying the time to a particular Geolcoation measurement. The simplest option is to have an Oracle that generates a proof of geolocation and time. I will expand the integration oracle with those options soon.

Regarding how to implement it, think of this way:

1. Obtain an authenticated geolocation. Let's call this Proof 1
2. Pass Proof 1 as a recursive zkSNARK to a circuit grabs the public output of Proof 1 and adds to it a timestamp

messages.content: @devtonite when designing recursive zkSNARKs (which is what you can do with Mina) circuits it's useful to think that each circuit generates a cryptographic Zero-Knowledge commitment to somthing. "Commitment" is a synonym of hash (more specifically, a cryptographic hash). You can then pass those commitments into other ZK circuits and expand that commitment with more data. You can do it by hashing the first commitment with any additional data. Try making each circuit as small as possible.

@devtonite once again, thank you so much for the questions. I'll aslo be making some explanatory videos. Right now, the focus is on finalizing the product for the deadline of January 12th. Additionally, I'll be making a proposal for zkCohort 3, which is an expansion of zkLocus into a major use case.

My girlfriend is a lawyer (fields of cybersecurity & international law), and we're are also making a proposal for the United Nations. It relates to the application and enforcement of the International Law, with use-cases expanding to warfare. One of the use-cases reduction of casualties in national and international military conflicts. The system is built on Mina using zkLocus as the basis for a verifiable, authenticated geolocation.

For now, I'm the only person architecting, developing and managing the product. As such, it's really necessary to manage the time carefully 🙂

Any questions or requests you have, please let me know! I will make sure that you'll get an answer. This also helps massively in terms of maximizing the value of the produced content

💜

@devtonite oh, and regarding the time, I'll be working on implementing arbitrary metadata association to a geolocation proof. This includes, timestamps, videos, images, text, and anything that can be represented as bytes 😄 

This means you can cryptographically associate geolcoation to a video, a tweet, a message, etc.
or anything that can be represented as NFTs))

Yess!

@DFST I know that you're working on NFTs on Mina. If you have any feedback, a use-case, or questions, please let me know. I can expand zkLocus with NFT-specific API and structure.

Make the circuits small and many, where each adds a bit more info to the overall proof.
